Small Business Social Media: Which Networks Are Right for You?

Social media networks are fantastic resources for small businesses to promote their brands online. The platforms themselves are free to use, and most also have paid advertising options if you want to run a product-focused campaign or reach new audiences.

But just because your business should be on social media, that doesn’t mean your business needs to be on every network. It’s important that you choose and maintain the social tools that work best for your vertical. That way you can most effectively reach your customers, without spreading yourself too thin.

Getting Started with Small Business Social

There are tons of social driven platforms out there, but let’s start out with the biggies. Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and Instagram are the most widely known social networks. And each comes with its own unique benefits to your small business.

As you evaluate the networks below, ask yourself the following questions. Your answers will help you determine which is the best bet for your small business:

  • What is the unique purpose of this platform?
  • How does it relate to my business?
  • Which target audience will it help me to connect with?
  • How much ongoing time and cost is required for it to have the best impact?

Facebook

Because everybody and their mother is on Facebook, the preeminent social network can be a strong tool for building brand loyalty and reputation. It’s also an opportunity to boost your brand authority through interesting content and engaging conversation.

Unique Attributes

  • Average Age of Users: 25-45 years
  • Gender Use: 60% female, 40% male
  • How often should I post?: 1-2 times per day

Keep in mind that organic reach on Facebook is limited, meaning you may have to “pay to play”–at least at first. Invest in Facebook only if you’re willing to run the occasional paid campaign to generate brand awareness or drive users toward special offers. And remember to share both your own, and third-party content to avoid exhausting your audience with overly promotional posts.

Twitter

Twitter is great for sharing breaking news and quick updates. It’s also a good way to collect instant feedback from your customers, if you’re into that sort of thing.

Unique Attributes

  • Average Age of Users: 18-29 years
  • Gender Use: 50% female, 50% male
  • How often should I post?: 3-4 times per day

Depending on your audience, Twitter can be fun–or a total flop. Media sites do well on Twitter, so if you’ve got, say, a food blog where you’re constantly posting new content, Twitter might be a good fit. But service-focused small businesses (a spa, salon, or restaurant, for example) might find their efforts more useful elsewhere.

If you do decide to invest time on Twitter, always include an image with your posts. Tweets that contain images are 34% more likely to get retweeted that tweets without images, according to Postcron.

Pinterest

Pinterest can act as an online scrapbook by showcasing products and the essence of your brand. Share snapshots of your latest displays, close-ups of your favorite products, and curated clips from third-party sources whose offerings compliment (but don’t compete with) your own.

Unique Attributes

  • Average Age of Users: 20-40 years
  • Gender Use: 80% female, 20% male
  • How often should I post?: 2-3 times per day

Pinterest is great if you’ve got compelling photography and strong visual appeal. With regard to small businesses, Pinterest is an excellent choice for retail shops with unique offerings and businesses offering aesthetic services like salons and spas.

Instagram

Instagram gives you the unique ability to augment your brand with visual content, and provides a number of filters to give your photos a look and feel that reflects your specific brand identity.

Unique Attributes

  • Average Age of Users: 16-34 years
  • Gender Use: 60% female, 40% male
  • How often should I post?: 1-2 times per day

Like Pinterest, Instagram is great if you’ve got strong graphic content and an eye for photography. Generally appealing to a younger demographic than Facebook, Instagram is the place to be for stylish services and pretty products. Effective use of hashtags can help spread your message to like-minded IGers around the globe!

So which social networks should your small business start with?

It’s important not to feel pressured to be on every platform, and that your already busy staff can handle the additional responsibility. Start with the one(s) that connect you best with your audience and that you feel you can regularly manage, and make it a point to revisit your approach and adjust based on what is best for your business and your goals.
